title: Morocco Food Discovery App - Place Details & UGC Layer
description:
## Overview
This epic builds the place details experience and the User-Generated Content (UGC) layer that creates differentiation and value independent of the provider.

## Place Identity Model
Every place uses a namespaced `placeKey`:
- Google places: `placeKey = 'g:' + place_id`
- Curated-only: `placeKey = 'c:' + slug`
- Future providers: `placeKey = '<provider>:' + id`

All UGC references placeKey, not Convex doc IDs. This enables:
- Provider-agnostic community content
- Smooth migration if provider changes
- Curated places that don't need provider backing

## Place Details Flow
1. User clicks place → fetch provider details with FieldMask
2. Join with owned data by placeKey (reviews, favorites, tags, notes)
3. Render combined view: provider content (ephemeral) + owned overlays (persistent)
4. Provider content NEVER persisted, NEVER cached beyond response

## What to Order (New Feature)
Top dishes derived from:
- UGC `dishesTried` aggregated in placeDishes table
- Editorial `mustTry` from curated cards

This is a differentiator: Google doesn't know what specific dishes are good at a restaurant.

## UGC Photo Moderation (Improved)
Original plan had `photoStorageIds` on reviews - no moderation metadata.

New ugcPhotos table provides:
- Per-photo moderation status (pending/approved/rejected)
- EXIF stripping (privacy)
- Blurhash + perceptual hash (spam/dup detection)
- NSFW scores from Cloud Vision
- Independent lifecycle from reviews

## Reviews with Structure
- One review per user per place (edit, don't duplicate)
- Structured fields: rating, dishesTried, pricePaidBucketMad, visitContext
- Helpful votes with count denormalization
- Edit history for moderation audit

## Personal Notes & Nicknames
Users can add private notes + nicknames to saved places:
- Helps offline recognition
- Enhances list clarity
- Entirely owned data

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Place details load P95 <800ms
- [ ] UGC photos have full moderation pipeline
- [ ] 'What to order' showing meaningful suggestions
- [ ] Reviews enforcing one-per-user-per-place

title: Implement place details page with provider + owned data
description:
## Task
Build the place details page that combines ephemeral provider data with persistent owned data.

## URL Structure
- Provider places: `/place/g/[googlePlaceId]`
- Curated places: `/place/c/[slug]`

## Data Flow
```
User clicks place
    ↓
Derive placeKey from URL (g:xxx or c:xxx)
    ↓
Parallel fetch:
  1. Provider details (if g: prefix) via ProviderGateway
  2. Owned data via Convex query (reviews, favorites, tags, notes)
    ↓
Render combined view
```

## Provider Data (Ephemeral)
Fetched fresh, never persisted:
- displayName, formattedAddress
- regularOpeningHours
- rating, userRatingCount
- photos (references only)
- websiteUri, phoneNumber

## Owned Data (Persistent)
From Convex by placeKey:
- Community rating (communityRatingAvg/Count)
- Favorites count
- Taste tags with votes
- User reviews
- Personal note/nickname (if user has one)
- Curated card data (if exists)

## Page Sections
1. **Header**: Name, address, rating badges
2. **Photo gallery**: Provider photos + UGC photos
3. **What to order**: Top dishes (owned)
4. **Curated card**: Editorial tips (if exists)
5. **Actions**: Call, Directions, Share, Save
6. **Taste tags**: Community voting
7. **Reviews**: With helpful votes

## No-Store Directive
```typescript
// app/place/g/[googlePlaceId]/page.tsx
export const dynamic = 'force-dynamic';
export const revalidate = 0;

export async function generateMetadata() {
  return {
    robots: 'noindex', // Don't index provider-backed pages
  };
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Provider details fetching correctly
- [ ] Owned data overlaying correctly
- [ ] No-store headers set
- [ ] Actions (call/directions/share) working

title: Implement review CRUD with one-per-user-per-place
Implement UGC photo upload with moderation pipeline
description:
## Task
Build the UGC photo upload system with full moderation pipeline (EXIF stripping, NSFW detection, approval flow).

## Upload Flow
```
User selects photo(s)
    ↓
Client-side validation (size, type)
    ↓
Upload to Convex storage
    ↓
Create ugcPhotos record (status: pending)
    ↓
Trigger moderation action:
  1. Strip EXIF metadata
  2. Generate thumbnail + blurhash
  3. Calculate perceptual hash
  4. Call Cloud Vision SafeSearch
    ↓
Auto-approve if clean, hold if flagged
```

## ugcPhotos Schema
```typescript
ugcPhotos: defineTable({
  uploaderUserId: v.id('users'),
  placeKey: v.string(),
  reviewId: v.optional(v.id('reviews')),
  storageId: v.id('_storage'),
  moderationStatus: v.string(), // 'pending' | 'approved' | 'rejected'
  nsfwScore: v.optional(v.number()),
  width: v.optional(v.number()),
  height: v.optional(v.number()),
  blurhash: v.optional(v.string()),
  perceptualHash: v.optional(v.string()),
  exifStripped: v.boolean(),
  createdAt: v.number(),
})
```

## EXIF Stripping
Privacy critical - remove:
- GPS coordinates
- Device info
- Timestamps
- Any identifying metadata

Use sharp or similar library in Convex action.

## Blurhash Generation
For loading placeholders:
```typescript
import { encode } from 'blurhash';
const blurhash = encode(imageData, width, height, 4, 3);
```

## Perceptual Hash
For duplicate/spam detection:
- Calculate phash of resized thumbnail
- Store for comparison
- Flag if matches recently uploaded photos from different users

## NSFW Detection
```typescript
// Call Google Cloud Vision SafeSearch
const result = await vision.safeSearchDetection(imageUri);
const nsfwScore = calculateNsfwScore(result.safeSearchAnnotation);

if (nsfwScore > NSFW_THRESHOLD) {
  await holdForModeration(photoId);
} else {
  await autoApprove(photoId);
}
```

## Constraints
- Max 5 photos per review
- Max 10MB per photo
- JPEG/PNG/WebP only

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Upload working with validation
- [ ] EXIF stripped on all photos
- [ ] Blurhash generated
- [ ] NSFW detection triggering holds
- [ ] Moderation queue queryable

Morocco Food Discovery App - Curated Content & Dish Explorer
description:
## Overview
This epic builds the editorial/curated content layer and the Dish Explorer feature - key differentiators that work entirely on owned data and function even when providers are unavailable.

## Strategic Importance
The biggest product risk is being 'Google Maps, but smaller.' We differentiate by going **dish-first** and **local context-first** using owned content.

## Curated Place Cards
Editorial content YOU own:
- Title, summary, neighborhood
- Must-try dishes, tips, price notes (MAD)
- Etiquette notes (cash-only, reservation needed, etc.)
- Amenities tags (Wi-Fi, family-friendly, vegetarian/halal)
- Cover photos (owned, not provider)

**Key benefit**: Powers SEO, offline mode, and degraded mode backbone.

## Dish Explorer (New V1 Feature)
Browse by dish + city → 'top places for this dish'

Ranking uses **owned signals only**:
- Favorites count
- Dish mentions (`placeDishes.mentionsCount`)
- Review recency

### placeDishes Schema
```typescript
placeDishes: defineTable({
  placeKey: v.string(),
  dish: v.string(),             // normalized key, e.g. 'tagine'
  mentionsCount: v.number(),
  lastMentionedAt: v.number(),
  updatedAt: v.number(),
})
```

## Home Page Dish Quick-Picks
New addition to MVP:
- Tagine, Couscous, Pastilla, Seafood, Coffee, Pastries
- One tap → dish explorer filtered to that dish
- Works in degraded mode (owned data only)

## Editorial Guides
Curated lists like 'Best tagine in Marrakech':
- Owned content with placeKeys
- SEO-friendly URLs (/guides/{slug})
- Featured on home page
- Works offline/degraded

## Degraded Mode Backbone
Curated content is the fallback when provider is unavailable:
- Mode 2: curated + owned search only
- Mode 3: curated cards + notes only
- Always available, always fast

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Dish Explorer showing meaningful results
- [ ] Home page dish quick-picks working
- [ ] Curated cards powering degraded mode
- [ ] Guides generating SEO traffic

title: Implement curated place cards system
description:
## Task
Build the editorial curated place cards - owned content that powers SEO, offline, and degraded mode.

## What Curated Cards Contain
All OWNED content (no provider data):
- title: Display name we own
- slug: URL-friendly identifier
- summary: Editorial description
- mustTry: Array of recommended dishes
- priceNote: e.g., '30-70 MAD'
- tags: Amenities/vibes (cash-only, wifi, family)
- coverStorageId: Our own photo
- neighborhood, city
- linkedPlaceKey: Optional link to provider place

## Schema
```typescript
curatedPlaces: defineTable({
  title: v.string(),
  slug: v.string(),
  city: v.string(),
  neighborhood: v.optional(v.string()),
  placeKey: v.string(),                 // 'c:' + slug
  linkedPlaceKey: v.optional(v.string()), // 'g:...' if linked
  summary: v.string(),
  mustTry: v.optional(v.array(v.string())),
  priceNote: v.optional(v.string()),
  tags: v.optional(v.array(v.string())),
  coverStorageId: v.optional(v.id('_storage')),
  locale: v.string(),
  publishedAt: v.optional(v.number()),
  featured: v.boolean(),
  sortOrder: v.number(),
})
  .index('by_slug', ['slug'])
  .index('by_city_featured', ['city', 'featured', 'sortOrder']),
```

## Two Types of Curated Places

### Standalone (placeKey = 'c:xxx')
- No provider backing
- All content is owned
- Works completely offline

### Linked (placeKey = 'c:xxx', linkedPlaceKey = 'g:yyy')
- Editorial overlay on provider place
- Can show provider details when available
- Falls back to curated card when provider unavailable

## Admin CRUD
```typescript
export const createCuratedPlace = mutation({
  args: { /* ... */ },
  handler: async (ctx, args) => {
    await requireRole(ctx, ['admin', 'editor']);
    
    const placeKey = `c:${args.slug}`;
    
    // Create curated place
    await ctx.db.insert('curatedPlaces', {
      ...args,
      placeKey,
      createdAt: Date.now(),
    });
    
    // Also create places anchor for UGC
    await ctx.db.insert('places', {
      placeKey,
      communityRatingCount: 0,
      favoritesCount: 0,
      createdAt: Date.now(),
      lastSeenAt: Date.now(),
    });
    
    // Audit log
    await logAction(ctx, 'curatedPlace.create', placeKey);
  },
});
```

## Featured on Home
Query for featured curated places by city:
```typescript
export const getFeaturedPlaces = query({
  args: { city: v.string() },
  handler: async (ctx, { city }) => {
    return ctx.db
      .query('curatedPlaces')
      .withIndex('by_city_featured', (q) =>
        q.eq('city', city).eq('featured', true)
      )
      .order('asc')
      .take(10);
  },
});
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Curated place CRUD working
- [ ] Both standalone and linked types supported
- [ ] Featured places query working
- [ ] Admin-only access enforced

title: Implement Dish Explorer feature
Implement editorial guides
description:
## Task
Build the editorial guides system - curated lists like 'Best tagine in Marrakech'.

## What Guides Contain
- title: e.g., 'Best Tagine in Marrakech'
- slug: URL-friendly (/guides/best-tagine-marrakech)
- description: Editorial intro
- coverImageUrl: Featured image (owned)
- placeKeys: Array of places in the guide
- city, categorySlug: For filtering
- locale: ar/fr/en

## Schema
```typescript
guides: defineTable({
  title: v.string(),
  slug: v.string(),
  description: v.string(),
  coverImageUrl: v.string(),
  city: v.optional(v.string()),
  categorySlug: v.optional(v.string()),
  placeKeys: v.array(v.string()),
  authorId: v.optional(v.id('users')),
  publishedAt: v.optional(v.number()),
  featured: v.boolean(),
  sortOrder: v.number(),
  locale: v.string(),
})
  .index('by_slug', ['slug'])
  .index('by_city', ['city'])
  .index('by_featured', ['featured', 'sortOrder']),
```

## Guide Page
```
/guides/[slug]
    ↓
Fetch guide by slug
    ↓
For each placeKey in guide:
  - If 'c:' prefix: show curated card only
  - If 'g:' prefix: try provider details, fall back to owned data
    ↓
Render list with editorial context
```

## SEO Considerations
Guides are great for SEO because:
- Owned content (can be indexed)
- Keyword-rich titles
- Structured data (ItemList schema)

```typescript
// app/guides/[slug]/page.tsx
export async function generateMetadata({ params }) {
  const guide = await getGuide(params.slug);
  return {
    title: guide.title,
    description: guide.description,
    openGraph: {
      images: [guide.coverImageUrl],
    },
  };
}
```

## Featured on Home
```typescript
export const getFeaturedGuides = query({
  args: { city: v.optional(v.string()), locale: v.string() },
  handler: async (ctx, { city, locale }) => {
    let query = ctx.db
      .query('guides')
      .withIndex('by_featured', (q) => q.eq('featured', true));
    
    const guides = await query.collect();
    
    return guides
      .filter(g => g.locale === locale)
      .filter(g => \!city || g.city === city)
      .sort((a, b) => a.sortOrder - b.sortOrder)
      .slice(0, 6);
  },
});
```

## Admin Interface
- Create/edit guides
- Reorder places in guide
- Set featured status
- Preview before publish

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Guide CRUD working
- [ ] Guide page rendering place list
- [ ] SEO metadata generating
- [ ] Featured guides on home page
- [ ] Works in degraded mode (owned content)

title: Morocco Food Discovery App - Observability & Reliability
description:
## Overview
This epic implements comprehensive observability, SLOs, alerting, and reliability patterns to ensure the app is production-ready.

## Performance Targets
| Metric | Target |
|--------|--------|
| Search P95 (backend) | <100ms |
| Search P95 (e2e, provider hit) | <800ms |
| Search P95 (e2e, cache hit) | <300ms |
| Place detail P95 | <800ms |
| Map initial render | <2s |
| Time to interactive | <3s |

## Cost Metrics
- Google Places API calls/hour by endpoint type
- Cache hit rate (target: >70% after 30 days)
- Cost per active user per day
- Cost per user journey (autocomplete → selection → details)
- Photo proxy bandwidth
- FieldMask/SKU mix (Essentials vs Pro vs Enterprise)
- Cost spikes by feature flag

## Business Metrics
- Search-to-detail CTR
- Detail-to-favorite conversion
- Reviews per active user per week
- List creation rate
- Share events

## SLOs (Reliability Targets)
- Search success rate: 99.5% over 7 days
- Place page success rate: 99.5% over 7 days
- Error budget policy: >50% burned → auto-tighten limits + disable expensive features

## Alerting Thresholds
| Metric | Threshold | Action |
|--------|-----------|--------|
| API error rate | >5% for 5min | Page on-call, enable degraded mode |
| Search P95 | >2s for 10min | Warning |
| Daily API cost | > | Alert + emergency throttling |
| Cache hit rate | <50% for 1hr | Investigate |
| Review spam flags | >10/hour | Alert moderation |

## Synthetic Monitoring (Canaries)
Scheduled canary hitting:
- Provider health (lightweight call)
- Photo proxy endpoint
- Key user flows (search + details)

Canary failures → page on-call, optionally flip feature flags.

## Scheduled Safety Jobs (Cron)
- **Geo expiry purge**: Delete expired lat/lng rows
- **ID-only cache purge**: Delete expired mapTileCache + searchResultCache
- **Aggregates repair**: Recompute favoritesCount, communityRatingAvg/Count
- **Budget watchdog**: Flip feature flags if threshold crossed
- **Degraded mode manager**: Promote/demote based on health + error budget

## Observability Stack
- Sentry for errors (with provider content redaction)
- Custom metrics dashboard
- Real-time cost tracking

## Success Criteria
- [ ] All key metrics being captured
- [ ] Alerts firing on threshold breaches
- [ ] Canaries running and catching issues
- [ ] Cron jobs maintaining data hygiene
- [ ] SLO dashboards visible to team

Morocco Food Discovery App - Project Foundation & Infrastructure
description:
## Overview
This epic establishes the foundational infrastructure for the Morocco Food Discovery App. It covers repository setup, environment configuration, core dependencies, and the base architectural patterns that all other features will build upon.

## Strategic Importance
Getting the foundation right is critical because:
1. **Policy-first architecture** must be baked in from day one - retrofitting compliance is expensive and error-prone
2. **Cost controls** need to be structural, not bolted on - Google Places API costs can spiral quickly
3. **Developer experience** shapes velocity - proper tooling and patterns prevent friction later

## Key Decisions Made
- **Convex** for backend: Real-time by default, TypeScript end-to-end, serverless
- **Next.js 16.x** with App Router: Modern React patterns, explicit no-store for provider routes
- **Separate API keys**: Browser key (Maps JS) vs Server key (Places API) with different restrictions

## Success Criteria
- [ ] All environments (dev/staging/prod) properly isolated
- [ ] CI/CD pipeline running with compliance tests as gates
- [ ] Observability stack capturing metrics from first deploy
- [ ] Rate limiting and circuit breaker patterns in place before any provider calls

## Risks to Monitor
- Accidental key exposure in client bundles
- Missing env vars causing silent failures
- Convex schema migrations in production

title: Configure Google Cloud Console with dual API keys
description:
## Task
Set up Google Cloud project with properly separated API keys for browser vs server usage.

## Why Dual Keys
Security best practice - different restrictions for different contexts:

### Browser Key (Maps JS API)
- HTTP referrer restrictions (your domains only)
- Only enables Maps JavaScript API
- Can be exposed in client bundle (restricted)

### Server Key (Places API)
- IP restrictions OR no restrictions (server-only)
- Enables Places API (New)
- NEVER in client bundle
- Stored in Convex env + Next.js server env only

## Configuration Steps
1. Create Google Cloud project
2. Enable APIs:
   - Maps JavaScript API
   - Places API (New)
3. Create Browser API key with referrer restrictions
4. Create Server API key
5. Set quotas and budget alerts

## Quota Recommendations (Day 1)
- Places API: Start conservative, increase based on actual usage
- Set daily budget cap with alerts at 50%, 80%, 100%

## Environment Variables
```
# Client-side (public)
NEXT_PUBLIC_GOOGLE_MAPS_KEY=...

# Server-side (secret)
GOOGLE_PLACES_KEY=...  # In Convex env
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Both API keys created and working
- [ ] Browser key restricted to domains
- [ ] Server key stored securely
- [ ] Budget alerts configured
- [ ] Quotas set appropriately

Configure environment separation (dev/staging/prod)
description:
## Task
Set up proper environment separation to prevent accidents and enable safe testing.

## Environments

### Development
- Local Convex dev instance
- Google API keys with low quotas
- MSW mocking for most provider calls
- Hot reload, verbose logging

### Staging
- Separate Convex project
- Separate Google API keys (still restricted)
- Real provider calls but monitored
- Preview deployments on Vercel

### Production
- Production Convex project
- Production Google API keys with full quotas
- Budget alerts active
- Error budget tracking

## Environment Variables Pattern
```
# .env.local (dev)
NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL=https://xxx.convex.dev
NEXT_PUBLIC_GOOGLE_MAPS_KEY=...
GOOGLE_PLACES_KEY=...

# Vercel env vars (staging/prod)
# Set separately per environment
```

## Key Principle
NEVER share API keys between environments. A staging incident shouldn't affect production budget.

## Convex Environment Setup
1. Create separate Convex projects: morocco-eats-dev, morocco-eats-staging, morocco-eats-prod
2. Use Convex dashboard to manage env vars per project

## Vercel Configuration
- Preview branches → staging Convex
- Main branch → production Convex
- Environment variables per deployment target

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Three environments properly isolated
- [ ] No shared API keys
- [ ] Vercel deployment targets configured
- [ ] Convex projects separated

title: Implement core Convex database schema
description:
## Task
Implement the complete Convex database schema as defined in the plan, including all new tables from the revisions.

## Schema Overview
The schema is policy-first: provider identifiers allowed, provider content forbidden.

## Core Tables

### User & Auth
- users - Basic profile + contribution stats
- userReputation - Trust tier tracking
- userRoles - RBAC for admin/moderation
- userPreferences - Settings

### Places (Policy-Safe Anchors)
- places - placeKey + provider refs + geo (with expiry) + aggregates
- curatedPlaces - Owned editorial cards
- placeTags - Community taste tags
- placeDishes - Dish mentions (NEW from revisions)
- userPlaceNotes - Personal notes/nicknames

### ID-Only Caches (NEW from revisions)
- searchResultCache - `{cacheKey -> [placeKey...]}` with TTL
- mapTileCache - `{tileKey -> [placeKey...]}` with TTL, chunked

### UGC
- reviews - One per user per place
- reviewEdits - Edit history for audit
- reviewHelpful - Helpful votes
- ugcPhotos - NEW: Per-photo moderation status

title: Morocco Food Discovery App - Provider Gateway & Policy Engine
description:
## Overview
This epic implements the centralized Provider Gateway - the single enforcement surface for all external provider interactions. This is the most critical architectural component for policy compliance and cost control.

## Why This Architecture
The plan identified a major gap: the original design had PhotoProxyRoute calling GooglePlaces directly, bypassing policy enforcement. This creates:
- Budget/rate limit escape hatches
- Inconsistent logging/observability
- Degraded mode gaps (photos still expensive when search disabled)

**Solution**: ALL provider access flows through ProviderGateway, including the photo proxy. This gives us:
- One enforcement surface for budgets, circuit breaker, redaction, metrics
- Consistent feature-flag behavior
- Fewer special cases = fewer ToS violations

## Key Components
1. **ProviderGateway wrapper** - Central enforcement layer
2. **Field mask registry** - Pre-approved field sets only, no ad-hoc masks
3. **Budget guardrails** - Per-endpoint class limits (autocomplete/search/details/photos)
4. **Circuit breaker** - Closed → Open → Half-Open state machine
5. **Singleflight** - Request coalescing to prevent stampedes
6. **Priority classes** - Load shedding order: details > search > autocomplete > photos

## Policy Guardrails (Non-Negotiable)
- Never log full provider responses
- Analytics use placeKey only, never provider name/address
- Client storage: IDs + owned content drafts only
- Provider-backed Next.js routes must be no-store

## Places API (New) Alignment
- Health check uses proper format: `places.googleapis.com/v1/places/{placeId}`
- Field mask via `X-Goog-FieldMask` header (mandatory, no defaults)
- Localization defaults: `languageCode` from user locale, `regionCode: MA`

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Zero direct provider calls outside ProviderGateway
- [ ] Budget exceeded → automatic feature degradation
- [ ] Circuit breaker prevents cascade failures
- [ ] Compliance tests pass (no provider content in persistence/logs)

title: Morocco Food Discovery App - Map & Geospatial Features
description:
## Overview
This epic implements the map-first discovery experience with sophisticated performance optimizations and cost controls for map interactions.

## Key Challenge: Map Pan Stampedes
Map interactions generate LOTS of provider calls:
- Every pan triggers potential 'search this area'
- Zooming changes visible places
- Multiple concurrent users = amplified load

## Solution: ID-Only Tile Cache (Policy-Safe)
The mapTileCache table stores:
- `{tileKey -> [placeKey...]}` with TTL
- Geohash/S2 tiles with zoom-derived granularity
- Chunked documents to avoid oversized rows

**Why this is policy-safe**: We store ONLY IDs, never provider content. Provider content is fetched ephemerally and kept in-memory only.

## Performance Patterns

### Client-Side
- Debounce bounds changes (300ms)
- Throttle marker updates (max 1/100ms during pan)
- Maintain `seenTiles` set - only request newly-visible tiles
- Marker recycling (reuse instead of create/destroy)

### Server-Side
- Viewport buffer + strict post-filter
- Clustering when >50 markers visible
- Singleflight coalescing for concurrent tile requests
- Separate rate limit for map-pan vs text search

## ID-Only Tile Cache Schema
```typescript
mapTileCache: defineTable({
  tileKey: v.string(),           // e.g. 's2:12:89ab...'
  zoom: v.number(),
  chunk: v.number(),             // 0..N
  provider: v.string(),          // 'google'
  placeKeys: v.array(v.string()),// ID-only
  expiresAt: v.number(),
  createdAt: v.number(),
})
```

## Stampede Protection
- Cap concurrent provider calls (max 25 in-flight per region)
- Under load: serve cached tile IDs + 'results may be incomplete' hint
- Priority class: map pans are lower than explicit search/details

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Map tile cache reducing provider calls by >70%
- [ ] P95 pan-to-render <500ms with warm cache
- [ ] No stampedes even with concurrent users
- [ ] Graceful degradation to cache-only in Mode 2+

Implement ID-only map tile cache
description:
## Task
Implement the mapTileCache for storing place IDs per viewport tile (policy-safe, no provider content).

## Why Tile-Based Caching
Map pans generate lots of 'search this area' calls. Without caching:
- Every pan → provider call
- Multiple users panning same area → multiplied calls
- Popular areas (Jemaa el-Fna) get hammered

## Tile System
Use S2 or geohash cells:
- Zoom-derived granularity (coarser at low zoom)
- Predictable tile keys
- Efficient spatial queries

```typescript
function getTileKey(lat: number, lng: number, zoom: number): string {
  const precision = zoomToPrecision(zoom);
  const s2Cell = S2.latLngToCell(lat, lng, precision);
  return `s2:${precision}:${s2Cell.id()}`;
}
```

## Schema
```typescript
mapTileCache: defineTable({
  tileKey: v.string(),           // e.g. 's2:12:89ab...'
  zoom: v.number(),
  chunk: v.number(),             // 0..N for large tiles
  provider: v.string(),          // 'google'
  placeKeys: v.array(v.string()),// ID-only
  expiresAt: v.number(),
  createdAt: v.number(),
})
  .index('by_tile', ['tileKey', 'zoom', 'chunk'])
  .index('by_expiry', ['expiresAt']),
```

## Chunking
Large tiles (zoomed out) might have 1000+ places. Chunk to avoid oversized documents:
- Max 100 placeKeys per chunk
- Query all chunks for a tile
- Write new chunks as needed

## Cache Flow
```
Map bounds change
    ↓
Calculate visible tiles
    ↓
Check client seenTiles set (already loaded?)
    ↓
For unseen tiles: query mapTileCache
    ↓
HIT: Use cached placeKeys → fetch fresh details for visible
MISS: Call provider (bounded search) → cache placeKeys → return
```

## TTL Strategy
- 30-60 minute TTL
- Longer than search cache (places don't move)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Tile key generation correct
- [ ] Cache hits working
- [ ] Chunking handling large tiles
- [ ] Cache reducing provider calls >70%

title: Morocco Food Discovery App - Search Architecture
description:
## Overview
This epic implements the two-track search architecture that cleanly separates provider discovery from owned content enrichment. This resolves a critical inconsistency in the original plan.

## The Problem We're Solving
The original plan stated: 'Convex search index for cached places + Google fallback'

But policy says: DON'T persist provider place content (name/address/etc).

**Contradiction**: You can't build a text search index over places you don't have text for.

## The Solution: Two-Track Search

### Track 1: Provider Discovery (Places)
- Google Places (New) Text Search / Nearby Search
- Returns ephemeral provider content for rendering
- Returns place IDs for joining with owned data
- Results cached as **ID-only** in searchResultCache (policy-safe)

### Track 2: Owned Search (Food Intent)
- Convex search indexes over owned content only:
  - Dish mentions from `dishesTried` + editorial `mustTry`
  - Curated place cards (title, summary, tags)
  - Guides and lists
  - Review text
  - Taste tags

## Cost Optimization Patterns
1. **Session tokens** - Group autocomplete → selection → details into one billing session
2. **Debounced input** - Don't fire on every keystroke
3. **Request coalescing** - Dedupe identical in-flight requests
4. **ID-only search cache** - Avoid repeat searches for same query
5. **Strict field masks** - Only request fields actually displayed

## Transliteration Support
Morocco is AR/FR/EN heavy. Need to normalize variants:
- tagine ↔ tajine ↔ طاجين
- couscous ↔ كسكس

## Popular Searches Privacy
Added k-anonymity threshold (≥20 unique users) + email/phone/URL filtering to prevent accidental PII exposure in trending queries.

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Clear separation: provider search vs owned search
- [ ] ID-only search cache reducing repeat provider calls
- [ ] Transliteration working across AR/FR/EN
- [ ] Popular searches privacy compliant

## Task
Implement the searchResultCache table to store ID-only results from repeated searches, reducing provider calls.

## Why This is Policy-Safe
We store ONLY:
- Cache key (hash of query + filters)
- Array of placeKeys ('g:ChIJ...')
- TTL metadata

We do NOT store:
- Place names, addresses, ratings
- Any provider content fields

## Schema
```typescript
searchResultCache: defineTable({
  cacheKey: v.string(),          // hash(query+filters+city+lang+mode)
  provider: v.string(),          // 'google'
  placeKeys: v.array(v.string()),// ID-only ('g:...' or 'c:...')
  expiresAt: v.number(),
  createdAt: v.number(),
})
  .index('by_key', ['cacheKey'])
  .index('by_expiry', ['expiresAt']),
```

## Cache Key Generation
```typescript
function searchCacheKey(params: SearchParams): string {
  const normalized = {
    query: normalizeQuery(params.query),
    city: params.city,
    filters: sortObject(params.filters),
    language: params.language,
  };
  return hash(JSON.stringify(normalized));
}
```

## Cache Flow
```
Search request
    ↓
Check searchResultCache by cacheKey
    ↓
HIT: Return cached placeKeys → fetch fresh details for top N
MISS: Call provider → store placeKeys → return
```

## TTL Strategy
- Short TTL: 15-30 minutes
- Reasoning: Place existence doesn't change often, but rankings might

## Cache Purge
Scheduled job (ID-only cache purge) deletes expired entries.

## Metrics
- search_cache_hit_rate (gauge)
- search_cache_entries (gauge)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Cache key generation deterministic
- [ ] Cache hits returning placeKeys
- [ ] TTL expiration working
- [ ] Purge job cleaning up expired entries

Implement Popular Searches with privacy guardrails
description:
## Task
Implement trending searches feature with privacy protections (k-anonymity, PII filtering).

## Privacy Risks
Without guardrails, popular searches could expose:
- Uniquely identifying queries ('my friend Ahmed's restaurant')
- Phone numbers/emails pasted into search
- Sensitive personal intent

## Privacy Guardrails

### K-Anonymity Threshold
Only display queries with ≥20 unique users:
```typescript
const MIN_USERS_FOR_DISPLAY = 20;

async function getPopularSearches(city: string) {
  const aggregates = await db.query('searchAggregates')
    .filter(q => q.eq(q.field('city'), city))
    .filter(q => q.gte(q.field('uniqueUsers'), MIN_USERS_FOR_DISPLAY))
    .order('desc', 'count')
    .take(10);
  
  return aggregates.map(a => a.normalizedQuery);
}
```

### PII Filtering
Drop queries containing:
- Email patterns: `/[a-z]+@[a-z]+\.[a-z]+/i`
- Phone patterns: `/\+?\d{10,}/`
- URL patterns: `/https?:\/\//`

```typescript
function containsPII(query: string): boolean {
  const patterns = [
    /[a-z0-9._%+-]+@[a-z0-9.-]+\.[a-z]{2,}/i,
    /\+?\d{10,}/,
    /https?:\/\//,
  ];
  return patterns.some(p => p.test(query));
}
```

### Retention Policy
- Raw per-user query logs: 24-hour TTL max
- Normalized aggregates: 30-day rolling window
- Never store raw queries long-term

## Aggregation Flow
```
User searches 'best tagine'
    ↓
Log to recentSearches (short TTL)
    ↓
Daily cron job aggregates:
  - Normalize queries
  - Filter PII
  - Count unique users
  - Store in searchAggregates
    ↓
Popular searches query reads aggregates
```

## Schema Addition
```typescript
searchAggregates: defineTable({
  normalizedQuery: v.string(),
  city: v.string(),
  count: v.number(),
  uniqueUsers: v.number(),
  periodStart: v.number(),
  periodEnd: v.number(),
}).index('by_city_count', ['city', 'count']),
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] K-anonymity threshold enforced
- [ ] PII patterns filtered
- [ ] Raw logs not retained beyond 24h
- [ ] Popular searches displaying correctly

title: Morocco Food Discovery App - Service Modes & Graceful Degradation
description:
## Overview
This epic implements the multi-level Service Mode system that replaces the binary 'Full vs Degraded' approach with progressive shedding.

## Why Multi-Level Modes
Original plan: basically on/off for degraded mode.

**Problem**: Reliability and cost incidents benefit from progressive shedding, not all-or-nothing.

**Solution**: Service Mode Levels 0-3

## Service Mode Table

| Mode | Trigger | Autocomplete/Search | Place Details | Photos | Map Pans |
|------|---------|---------------------|--------------|--------|----------|
| 0 (Normal) | healthy + budget ok | ✅ provider-first | ✅ provider-first | ✅ enabled | ✅ enabled |
| 1 (Cost-Saver) | cost spike OR latency spike | ✅ provider-first (tighter limits) | ✅ (lite fields) | ❌ disabled | ✅ ID-only cache first |
| 2 (Provider-Limited) | provider errors OR breaker open | ❌ (curated + owned search only) | ✅ only for saved/opened places | ❌ | ✅ ID-only cache only |
| 3 (Offline/Owned Only) | offline OR emergency | ❌ | ❌ (owned cards + notes only) | ✅ UGC only | ✅ saved/curated only |

## Benefits of Progressive Degradation
1. **Smoother UX** - Features disappear gradually, not suddenly
2. **Cheaper mitigation** - Turn off expensive surfaces first (photos → open-now → autocomplete)
3. **Clearer operations** - 'We're in Mode 2 because budget exceeded'

## UI Behavior by Mode
- **Mode 1**: Subtle note only if user hits disabled feature ('Reduced features to keep things fast')
- **Mode 2+**: Non-intrusive banner + explicit 'Browse guides/lists/saved places' affordances
- Auto-dismiss when service recovers

## Mode Manager Logic
The system mode manager decides current mode based on:
1. Health check status (is provider responding?)
2. Budget status (daily limits exceeded?)
3. Error budget burn rate (SLO violation rate)
4. Circuit breaker state

## Auto-Mitigation Playbook
When error budget burns >50%:
1. Disable photos first (most expensive)
2. Disable open-now filter
3. Reduce max results / pagination
4. Fall back to Mode 2 (curated + community only)

## Health Check (Places API New)
```typescript
const response = await fetch(
  `https://places.googleapis.com/v1/places/${placeId}`,
  {
    headers: {
      'Content-Type': 'application/json',
      'X-Goog-Api-Key': process.env.GOOGLE_PLACES_KEY\!,
      'X-Goog-FieldMask': 'id',
    },
  }
);
```

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Mode transitions happening automatically on triggers
- [ ] UI adapting to current mode
- [ ] Cost savings measurable in Mode 1
- [ ] App usable in Mode 2-3 with owned data

```yaml
- name: Compliance Tests
  run: npm run test:compliance
  # These tests verify:
  # - No provider content in persistence
  # - No provider content in analytics
  # - Provider routes are no-store
  # - No provider content in Sentry config
```

### 4. Integration Tests
```yaml
- name: Integration Tests
  run: npm run test:integration
```

### 5. E2E Tests
```yaml
- name: E2E Tests
  run: npm run test:e2e
```

### 6. Deploy to Staging
```yaml
- name: Deploy to Staging
  if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/main'
  run: vercel deploy --prebuilt
```

### 7. Canary Tests
```yaml
- name: Canary Tests
  run: npm run test:canary -- --env staging
```

### 8. Deploy to Production
```yaml
- name: Deploy to Production
  if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/main'
  environment: production
  run: vercel deploy --prebuilt --prod
```

## Full Workflow File
```yaml
# .github/workflows/ci.yml
name: CI/CD

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  lint:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: '20'
          cache: 'npm'
      - run: npm ci
      - run: npm run lint
      - run: npm run typecheck

  test:
    needs: lint
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: '20'
          cache: 'npm'
      - run: npm ci
      - run: npm run test:coverage
      - name: Compliance Tests (GATE)
        run: npm run test:compliance

  e2e:
    needs: test
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
      - run: npm ci
      - run: npx playwright install --with-deps
      - run: npm run test:e2e

  deploy-staging:
    needs: e2e
    if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/main'
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    environment: staging
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: amondnet/vercel-action@v20
        with:
          vercel-token: ${{ secrets.VERCEL_TOKEN }}
          vercel-org-id: ${{ secrets.VERCEL_ORG_ID }}
          vercel-project-id: ${{ secrets.VERCEL_PROJECT_ID }}

  deploy-production:
    needs: deploy-staging
    if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/main'
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    environment: production
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: amondnet/vercel-action@v20
        with:
          vercel-token: ${{ secrets.VERCEL_TOKEN }}
          vercel-args: '--prod'
```

## Target: <15min Total Pipeline

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Pipeline runs on every PR
- [ ] Compliance tests blocking bad merges
- [ ] Staging deploys automatically
- [ ] Production requires manual approval
- [ ] Pipeline time <15 minutes

description:
## Overview
This epic implements the trust and safety layer: input validation, rate limiting, moderation workflows, RBAC for admins, and anti-abuse measures.

## Input Validation Constraints
| Field | Constraints |
|-------|-------------|
| Review text | 10-2000 chars, no URLs/emails |
| Review rating | Integer 1-5 |
| Dishes tried | 0-10 items, 1-40 chars each |
| Price paid | Optional bucket (<30, 30-70, 70-150, 150+ MAD) |
| List name | 1-100 chars |
| Report reason | 10-500 chars required |
| User name | 2-50 chars, alphanumeric + spaces |

## Rate Limiting (Granular)
| Action | Authenticated | Anonymous |
|--------|---------------|-----------|
| Search | 60/min | 20/min |
| Place detail | 30/min | 30/min |
| Review create | 5/hour | - |
| Photo upload | 10/hour | - |
| Report submit | 10/day | - |
| Favorite toggle | 60/min | - |

## UGC Photo Moderation (Enhanced)
Original: photos just stored as IDs on reviews.

New ugcPhotos table with full pipeline:
- EXIF stripping on upload (privacy)
- Cloud Vision SafeSearch (NSFW detection)
- Thumbnails + blurhash generation
- Perceptual hash for spam/duplicate detection
- Per-photo status: pending → approved/rejected
- Moderation queue queryable by status

## Reviewer Reputation
Trust tiers: new → regular → trusted

Based on:
- Account age
- Contribution quality (helpful votes)
- No moderation actions

**New/low-rep users**:
- Lower rate limits
- Reviews have 'cooldown' before public visibility

## Anti-Spam Measures
- Near-duplicate detection (hash/similarity on review text)
- Flag reviews with repetitive text across places
- One review per user per place (edit, don't duplicate)

## RBAC for Admin/Moderation
Roles: admin | moderator | editor

**Critical**: All mutations check RBAC server-side (never client-side gating only).

## Audit Logging
All privileged actions write immutable audit log:
- actor, action, target, timestamp
- Used for moderation disputes and compliance

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Input validation preventing malformed data
- [ ] Rate limits enforced per action type
- [ ] Photo moderation queue functional
- [ ] Reputation tiers affecting visibility
- [ ] Audit log capturing all privileged actions

Morocco Food Discovery App - Photo Proxy & Security Hardening
description:
## Overview
This epic implements the photo proxy with proper security controls, signed URLs to prevent hotlinking, and broader security hardening measures.

## Photo Proxy Architecture
Single Next.js Route Handler: `/api/photos/{placeId}/{photoRef}`

**Critical change from original plan**: Photo proxy now flows through ProviderGateway, not directly to Google. This ensures:
- Budget enforcement
- Circuit breaker protection
- Consistent metrics/logging
- Feature flag respect (photos disabled in Mode 1+)

## Signed URLs (Hotlink Prevention)
The photo proxy is expensive and easy to abuse. Solution:

```
/api/photos/{placeId}/{photoRef}?size=medium&exp=...&sig=...
```

Benefits:
- Third parties can't burn your budget via hotlinking
- Predictable cache keys
- Better incident response ('invalidate signatures' by rotating key)

## Cache Headers
Explicit and small TTL:
```
Cache-Control: public, s-maxage=900, max-age=300, stale-while-revalidate=60
```

- CDN caches for 15 minutes
- Browser caches for 5 minutes
- Stale-while-revalidate for graceful refresh

## Photo Proxy Features
- Server-side caching (short TTL, policy-safe)
- Image resizing (thumbnail, medium, full)
- WebP/AVIF format conversion
- API key never exposed to client
- No persistence of image bytes

## Security Hardening (Broader)

### Content Security Policy
Strict CSP suitable for Maps JS + your domains.

### Bot Protection
Progressive challenges for anonymous high-cost endpoints:
- Search
- Details
- Photos

### Key Security
- Browser key: Maps JS API only, HTTP referrer restrictions
- Server key: Places API only, Convex env + Next.js server env only
- NEVER in client bundles

### Error Reporting
Sentry with provider content redaction:
- beforeSend filtering
- Breadcrumb filtering
- No provider response bodies in error reports

### Service Worker Allowlist
- ✅ OK: /guides/*, /lists/* (owned), static assets
- ❌ Never: /place/* routes with provider fields, photo proxy responses

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Photo proxy using signed URLs in production
- [ ] Hotlinking attempts rejected
- [ ] CSP preventing XSS vectors
- [ ] API keys properly isolated
- [ ] No provider content in Sentry
